posts.cooked:
Hi everyone,

We have exciting news for Linux users! We’re planning to package Signal Desktop in the AppImage format, so that it will be officially available on all Linux distributions and not just Debian-based ones. The beta is available now and we’d appreciate your help testing it on your favorite Linux.

See below for notes, instructions and distribution-specific info. Please note some systems require prerequisite setup like installing FUSE. Testing on any Linux distro is helpful, even Debian-based ones. Let us know how it goes and thanks so much!

Notes

  • New data directory – The AppImage stores data separately from the Linux Deb at ~/.config/Signal Beta AppImage/. This also means the AppImage can run alongside the existing Linux Deb without affecting each other’s data.

  • Fresh link recommended – Although you could migrate data from the Linux Deb Beta, we recommend configuring the AppImage version as a new linked device and doing a fresh link (or link with synced history) from your primary Android/iOS device in order to avoid potential conflicts.

  • Prerequisite setup – Some Linux distributions (such as Ubuntu 24) may need to install FUSE 2 or add an AppArmor profile. See below for details.

  • Architecture – Only x86_64 is supported currently (but we want to improve this later).

Instructions

Download AppImage

Download and rename the AppImage without the version number, since auto updates will cause the installed version to get out of sync with the original filename.

wget -O signal-desktop-beta.AppImage https://updates.signal.org/desktop/signal-desktop-beta_7.82.0-beta.1_x86_64.AppImage

Verify GPG signature

We sign AppImage releases so you can verify the download was exactly as we built it. (These instructions assume GPG is already installed on your system.)

Download and import our GPG public key:

wget -O signal-appimage.asc https://updates.signal.org/static/desktop/appimage.asc
gpg --import signal-appimage.asc

Download signature and verify:

wget https://updates.signal.org/desktop/signal-desktop-beta_7.82.0-beta.1_x86_64.AppImage.gpg
gpg --verify signal-desktop-beta_7.82.0-beta.1_x86_64.AppImage.gpg signal-desktop-beta.AppImage

A good result looks like this:

gpg: Good signature from "Signal Messenger, LLC <support@signal.org>"

A bad result says “BAD signature”. That means the AppImage could not be verified. In that case you should not run the AppImage you downloaded, and please report the issue.

(Note: You may see a warning about trust. This is normal – roughly it means the signature was OK but the GPG key hasn’t been marked as trusted yet.)

gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!
gpg: There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.

You can locally sign the key to remove this warning:

gpg --lsign-key 4B16B7232DFAA439AD791002EF9F501F13EED94C

Run AppImage

Mark the AppImage runnable then run it.

chmod +x signal-desktop-beta.AppImage
./signal-desktop-beta.AppImage

Optional setup

System launcher integration

AppImages need extra setup to integrate with the system app launcher. One way to do this is to create a .desktop file:

touch ~/.local/share/applications/signal-beta-appimage.desktop

Then add this content, replacing the Exec path with the path to your AppImage, and ensuring that there isn’t a blank line at the start after pasting.

[Desktop Entry]
Name=Signal Beta AppImage
Exec=AppRun %U
Exec=/home/your-username/.local/bin/signal-desktop-beta.AppImage %F
Terminal=false
Type=Application
Icon=signal-desktop-beta
StartupWMClass=signal beta
Comment=Private messaging from your desktop
MimeType=x-scheme-handler/sgnl;x-scheme-handler/signalcaptcha;
Categories=Network;InstantMessaging;Chat;

Now you should be able to launch the app with your system launcher.

Prerequisite Setup / Distribution Specific Info

All

  • OS auth prompts are unavailable. This may limit optional features like viewing the Signal Backups key.

Ubuntu 24

FUSE 2 is required, and you need to add an AppArmor profile to set the correct user namespace permissions.

Install FUSE:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libfuse2t64

Add AppArmor profile:

Create this file:

sudo nano /etc/apparmor.d/signal-desktop-beta-appimage

With this content (No initial newline; and replace /path/to with your AppImage path):

profile signal-desktop-beta-appimage /path/to/signal-desktop-beta.AppImage flags=(unconfined) {
userns,
}

Then reload AppAmor:

sudo apparmor_parser -r /etc/apparmor.d/signal-desktop-beta-appimage
sudo systemctl reload apparmor
sudo systemctl daemon-reload

Debian

FUSE 2 is required.

Install FUSE:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libfuse2t64

posts.cooked: GPG is annoying because it requires a stateful keychain and any key inside it will be used to attempt verification of the artifact instead of just the Signal release key. I’d rather use SSH for signing, it allows verification with a specific key and it’s more likely to be preinstalled too.

ayumi-signal:

AppImage format, so that it will be officially available on all Linux distributions

AppImage will not work on all Linux distributions, at least the ones that are following immutable concept, where operating system is fully separated from end-user applications (just like phone or chromebook). You can’t use AppImage on Fedora Silverblue or Universal’s Blue variant Blufin (and similar Linux systems), because FUSE required by AppImage is not supported. On Blufin help is explicitly written: “Since Bluefin LTS is “bootc natural” and not a transplant, it comes with less compromises out of the box. Bluefin LTS doesn’t support local layering at all and AppImages don’t work either”.

My 2 cents, just looking at instructions how to install AppImage is quite a mess. Installing apps should be super easy and available from application stores with one click to install app. For example Blufin is using Bazaar GUI application store to install flatpaks. Bazaar is also installed as flatpak.

Signal Desktop for non-APT Linux distributions

Flathub doesn’t allow Signal to sign themselves the binary.

Is this really an issue? There are some flatpaks that are published on Flathub that are build outside the Flathub, for example Mozilla Firefox is completely build outside of Flathub on Mozilla infrastructure.

On the other hand flatpak build on Flathub it is required to provide manifest file, that is instructions how to download source code and build flatpak on Github. The same manifest file can be downloaded to PC and build locally and then compare if Github’s and local version are the same.

We have to understand that apps on Android and iOS are also out of control of Signal, but Signal can produce rebuild verification.

On Flathub there is unofficial flatpak and from manifest file we can se that flatpak is build from deb file. Not ideal, but it is fully reproducible.

posts.cooked:
I fresh installed Ubuntu 25.10 and did the test following all of the instructions from this forum thread first post for “Ubuntu” section.

First issue:

gpg --verify signal-desktop-beta_7.82.0-beta.1_x86_64.AppImage.gpg signal-desktop-beta.AppImage

returns error:

gpg: Signature made Thu 04 Dec 2025 12:05:30 AM CET
gpg: using RSA key 4B16B7232DFAA439AD791002EF9F501F13EED94C
gpg: Can’t check signature: No public key

I did not want to spend a time on playing with GPG, so I just continued.

Second issue:

When I executed:

./signal-desktop-beta.AppImage

it seems nothing happens, but then I spotted icon in system tray. I expected app to launch, just like Signal’s flatpak version. Clicked on icon on system tray and I could register and app seams to work fine.

Third issue:

Pressing “Super” key and type in Signal and “Signal Beta App Image” is displayed, but it looks it has no official Signal icon.

To fix this:

  • I have installed 7zip program: sudo apt install 7zip
  • I have copied signal-desktop-beta.AppImage to some new empty directory.
  • I have renamed file signal-desktop-beta.AppImage to signal-desktop-beta.7z
  • I have extracted AppImage: 7z e signal-desktop-beta.7z
  • I have copied file signal-desktop-beta.png to my path where signal-desktop-beta.AppImage file is located.
  • I have opened file ~/.local/share/applications/signal-beta-appimage.desktop file with text editor and changed “Icon” to absolute path of signal-desktop-beta.png file.
  • Waited few seconds e.g. 10 sec, because changing desktop file does not have immediate effect. Then I have pressed “Super” key again and typed in “Signal” and new icon is correctly displayed and when app is launched I can see this Signal icon on Dash and when pressing Alt+Tab key.

After all… playing along with app, it looks Signal AppImage works just fine (just like my Signal’s flatpak version).
